Notes on Weak and Weak∗ Topology

Weak Topology

Definition 1-1. The weak topology on Banach space X is defined is the coarsest topology such that each φ∈X∗ is continuous on X. Henceforth we assume X is always a Banach space, and denote its weak topology by σ(X,X∗).

Proposition 1-1. (X,σ(X,X∗)) is always Hausforff.

Proof. For each x≠y in this topology space, Hahn-Banach's theorem illustrates that there exists ℓ∈X∗ such that ℓ(x−y)≠0. Therefore, there exist two open neighbourhoods Ux,Uy such that ℓ→(Ux)∩ℓ→(Uy)=∅.

Here ℓ→ is defined P(X), ℓ→:A(⊂X)↦{ℓ(x):x∈A}.

◻

Definition 1-2. The sequence {xn}n≥1⊂X is weakly convergent to x0∈X whence ℓ(xn)→ℓ(x0) for each ℓ∈X∗. Henceforth we denote the weak convergence by xn⇀x0.

Here, weak convergence also means convergence in the weak topology (X,σ(X,X∗)).

Proposition 1-2. As a result, we have the following propositions:

(a) Weak convergence is a direct result of strong convergence, that is, convergence in (X,∥⋅∥X).

(b) Weak convergent sequence is bounded.

(c) If a sequence {xn}n≥1⊂X converges to x0 weakly, then ∥x0∥≤lim infn→∞∥xn∥.

(d) If xn⇀x0 in X and fn→f0 in X∗, then fn(xn)→f0(x0).

Proof. (a) Since |ℓ(x)−ℓ(y)|≤∥ℓ∥⋅∥x−y∥ for each ℓ∈X∗ and x,y∈X, it directly follows that xn→x0 implies xn⇀x0.

(b) Consider the canonical imbedding J:X→X∗∗,x↦(ℓ↦ℓ(x)). We claim it isomertric since

∥J(x)∥=sup∥ℓ∥=1∥(J(x))(ℓ)∥=sup∥ℓ∥=1|ℓ(x)|=∥x∥.

The final inequality is a corollary of Hahn-Banach's theorem.

The Banach-Steinhaus theorem reveals that if {(J(xn))(ℓ)}n≥1 is bounded for each ℓ∈X∗, then supn≥1∥J(xn)∥<∞. As a result, ∥xn∥<∞.

(c) Via Hahn-Banach's theorem, there exists ℓ0∈X∗ such that ℓ0(x0)=∥x0∥ and ∥ℓ0∥=1​. Then

∥x0∥=limn→∞|ℓ0(xn)|=lim infn→∞|ℓ0(xn)|≤∥ℓ0∥⋅lim infn→∞∥xn∥.

(d) Indeed, when xn(k)⇀x0(k) in Xk∗ (X∗⋯∗ with k ∗'s) for k=0,1,…,m−1 and xn(m)→x0(m). We have xn(m)xn(m−1)⋯xn(0)→x0(m)x0(m−1)⋯x0(0). Then

|xn(m)xn(m−1)⋯xn(0)−x0(m)x0(m−1)⋯x0(0)|=∑k=0m−1|xn(m)⋯xn(k+1)x0(k)⋯x0(0)−xn(m)⋯xn(k)x0(k−1)⋯x0(0)|=n→∞0.

◻

Proposition 1-3. For finite dimensional space V, the weak topology coincides the topology induced by norm.

Proof. Indeed, the weak topology coincides strong topology in V. Let {xn=(xn1,xn2,…,xnd)}n≥1⊂V be a sequence converging to x0=(x01,…,x0d) weakly. Then xn⇀x0​ implies that

ek(xn)→ek(x0),ek(∈V∗):x↦xk.

Thus ∥xn−x0∥≤∑i=1d|ek(xn−x0)|→0 as n→∞.

◻

Proposition 1-4. Let S⊂X be convex and closed (in norm sense) subset in Banach space X, then S is weakly closed.

Proof. For each x∉S, there exists linear map that seperates the compact convex set {x} and closed convex set S, i.e., ∃f∈X∗ such that inff→({x})≥α>β≥supf→(S).

Hence x is an exterior point of S in sense of weak topology.

◻

Lower Semi-continuity

Definition 2-1. f:X→R is called lower semi-continuous whence

f←((−∞,α]):={x∈X∣f(x)≤α}

is closed in X for each α∈R.

If follows that f(x0)≤liminfn→∞f(xn) as xn→x0 while f​ is semi-continuous. As shown in previous, norm function is also semi-continuous in the weak topology, i.e.,

∥x0∥≤lim infn→∞∥xn∥as xn⇀x0.

Definition 2-2. The Shur condition is that each sequence converges in norm topology whence it converges in weak topology. For instanse, the ℓ1 space satisfies such condition as follows.

Shur's lemma. In ℓ1 space, convergence in norm topology coincides the convergence in weak topology.

Proof. The convergence in norm topology implies weak convergence directly.

Conversely, we denote xk by the k-th entry of x. {ek}k≥1 be such that eij=δij. If xn↛0 in ℓ1, then there exists a subsequence {xnk}k≥1 such that ∥xnk∥ℓ1≥ε0 for some ε0>0. Without the loss of generality, let {xnk}k≥1 be {xn}n≥1 itself.

Let n0 be such that ∥(x1n0+1,x1n0+2,…)∥ℓ1<ε0/6. Then let T0(ei)=sgn(x1i) for each i≤n0 and T0(ei)=0 for the rest. There exists m1>1 such that ∥(xm11,xm12,…,xm1n0)∥ℓ1<ε0/6. We can take n1>n0 such that ∥(xm1n1+1,xm1n1+2,…)∥ℓ1<ε0/6. Let T1(ei)=sgn(xm1i) for each n0<i≤n1.

Let m0=1, n−1=0. Then for each p∈N∪{0} we can construct {(np,mp,Tp)} such that

  • ∥(xmp1,…,xmpnp−1+1)∥ℓ1<ε0/6, ∥(xmpnp+1,…)∥ℓ1<ε0/6.
  • Tp(ei)=sgn(xmpi) whence np−1+1≤i≤np, Tp(ei)=0 for the rest.

Therefore Tp(xmp)≥−2⋅(ε0/6)+ε0=2ε0/3. Since T:=∑p≥0Tp∈ℓ∞, it reveals that T(xmp)>ε0/2 for each p, which contradicts the definition of weak convergence.

◻

Weak Continuity

Definition 3-1. We say the linear mapping T:X→Y​ is weakly continuous whenever T​ is a continuous map in sense of weak topology, i.e.,

T:(X,σ(X,X∗))→(Y,σ(Y,Y∗))is continuous.

Proposition 3-1. The linear map T:X→Y is weakly continuous whenever

f∘T:X→F,x↦f∘T(x)

is weakly continuous for each f∈Y∗.

Proof. Let I denote any open set in F.

  • If T is weakly continuous, then f←(I) is weakly open in Y. Thus T←(f←(I))=(f∘T)←(I) is weakly open. It yields that f∘T is weakly continuous.
  • If f∘T is weakly continuous, then T←(f←(I))=(f∘T)←(I) is weakly open in X. By definition of weak open sets, the weakly open set in Y is a finite intersection of fj←(Ij) for j∈J<∞. Since the preimage of weakly open sets are weakly open in X, T is weakly continous.

◻

Proposition 3-2. The linear maps T:X→Y is continuous whenever it is weakly continuous.

Proof. ⇒: If T∈L(X,Y), then f∘T is weakly continuous for each y∈Y∗. Hence T is weakly continuous due to the previous lemma.

⇐: Let T be weakly continuous. Since the weak topology in Hausdorff, G(T) is closed in X×Y in the weak topology (the diagonal under the map Id×T is closed in Hausdorff space). The continuity of T is a consequence of closed graph theorem.

◻

Weak∗ Topology

Dual space X∗ is also endowed with the weak topology, which is coarsest topology such that each f∈X∗∗ is continuous on X∗​. Consider the canonical imbedding

J:X→X∗∗,x↦Jx,Jx:ℓ(∈X∗)↦ℓ(x).

Whenever X is not reflexive, the new topology of X∗ that each f∈J→(X)≅x is continuous on X∗ is coarser than (X∗,σ(X∗,X∗∗)). Hence we can define a new topology as follows.

Definition 4-1. The weak∗ topology on the dual space X∗ is defined is the coarsest topology such that each f∈J→(X∗∗)≅X is continuous on X∗. Henceforth we denote the weak∗ topology of X∗ by σ(X∗,X).

Proposition 4-1. When X∗ is reflexive, the weak and weak∗ topology coincides.

Proof. When X∗ is reflexive, the canonical imbedding J∗:X∗→X∗∗∗ is an isomorphism, thus J∗∗=(J∗∗)−1=(J∗−1)∗ is also an isomorphism. Hence X∗∗ is reflexive. Then J:X→X∗∗ is an isomorphism. It yields that the the weak and weak∗ topology coincides.

◻

Albeit coarser, the (X∗,σ(X∗,X)) is still Hausdorff.

Proposition 4-2. For dual space X∗ of each Banach space X, (X∗,σ(X∗,X)) is always Hausforff.

Proof. For each f1≠f2 in X∗, there exists x∈X such that ∥f1(x)−f2(x)∥=3ε0>0. We choose r=ε0∥x∥. Let

Ui:={g∈X∗∣∥g−fi∥≤r},i=1,2/

Then Jx(U1)∩Jx(U2)=∅. As a result, (X∗,σ(X∗,X)) is always Hausforff.

◻

Definition 4-2. The sequence {fn}n≥1⊂X∗ is said to be weakly∗ convergent whenever fn(x)→f(x) for each x∈X. We write weak∗ convergence as fn⇀∗f in X∗.

Proposition 4-3. fn→f⟹fn⇀f⟹fn⇀∗f.

Proof. This equivalents that normed topology is finer than weak topology, and much finer than weak∗ topology. fn→f⟹fn⇀f​ is already shown in the previous proposition. The latter is due to

[g(fn)→g(f)∀g∈X∗∗]⟹[Jx(fn)→Jx(f)∀x∈X].

◻

Banach-Alaoglu Theorem. The closed unit ball in X∗ is weak∗ compact.

Proof. By virture of Tychonoff's theorem, the product space

Y:=∏x∈X[−∥x∥,∥x∥]

with usual topology inherited from R is compact. For each f in B1∗, the closed unit ball in X∗, the map

φ:f↦φ(f)=(f(x))x∈X

leads a homeomorphism from B1∗ to φ(B1∗)⊂Y when the unit ball in X is endowed with the topology induced by the weak∗ topology of X∗. The boundedness of f shows that whenever f is linear, φ(B1∗) is closed, thus φ(B1∗) and B1∗ are compact.

We show that f(x+cy)=f(x)+cf(y) for each x,y,c. For arbitrarily small ε=ε(x,y,c)>0 There exists g∈B1∗ such that

|g(x)−f(x)|,|c|⋅|g(y)−f(y)|,|g(x+cy)−f(x+cy)|≤ε3.

Thus |f(x+cy)−f(x)−cf(y)|≤ε. It yields that f is linear.

◻

Weak Completeness

Definition 5-1. We say a topological space (X,τ) is metrisable whenever there exists a metric d that the induced topology of d coincides with (X,τ).

Proposition 5-2. The weak topology σ(X,X∗) is not metrisable whenever dim⁡X=∞.

Proof. It is clear that X∗ is metrisable when dim⁡X<∞ since the weak topology coincides strong topology. When X is infinite dimensional, we assume there exists a metric d in (X,σ(X,X∗)) for the sake of contradiction.

Let Bk:={x∈X∣d(x,0)<k−1} be a weak open neighbourhood of the origin. Then there exists a finite collection Fk⊂X∗ and εk>0 such that

Wk:={x∈X∣∥f(x)∥<εk,∀f∈Fk}⊂Bk.

Let F:=∪k≥1Fk be a countable subset of X∗. Take any g∈X∗ such that W={x∈X∣∥g(x)∥<1}. Then there exists N∈N such that Bk⊂W for each k≥1. As a consequence, Wk⊂W.

Now consider x∈∩f∈Fkker⁡f. Then λx∈Wk for each λ∈R. Since λx∈Wk⊂W, ∥g(λx)∥=|λ|∥g(x)∥<1. It yields that x∈ker⁡g.

We notice that f is a linear combination of {fi}i=1m whenever ∩i=1nker⁡fi⊂ker⁡f. Therefore, we deduce that X∗=span(F). Since F is consists countable union of finite dimensional spaces which is nowhere dense in X∗, it contradicts that X∗ is in category II.

◻

Due to the lack of metric for weak topology, the Cauchy sequences fail to illustrates the weak topology fully. This is why we utilise Cauchy net to study the weak completeness.

Definition 5-2. We say (X,σ(X,X∗)) is weakly complete (weakly sequentially complete, respectively) when the Cauchy net {xα}α∈A⇀x (Cauchy sequence {xn}n≥1⇀x, respectively).

Proposition 5-3. Weak completeness implies weakly sequential completeness. There exists a normed linear space which is weakly sequentially complete yet not weakly complete.

Proof. Since each sequence is a web, it directly follows that weak completeness implies weakly sequential completeness.

Conversely, the Banach space L([a,b]) is weakly sequentailly complete yet not weakly complete. We claim that {xn}n≥1⇀x whenever

  • supn≥1∥xn∥<∞,
  • For each Lebesgue measurable set E⊂[a,b], the limit limn→∞∫Exn exists.

This is due to each f∈L∞ can be approximated by step functions in L∞ sense. Equivalently, step functions are dense in L∞.

Take f∈L∞([a,b]). The limit limn→∞f(xn) exists. Then Banach-Steinhaus theory illustrates that ∥xn∥ is bounded. Hence xn⇀x by the claim above.

Since the weak topology of L([a,b]) no longer satisfies first axiom of countability, it is not weakly complete.

◻

Proposition 5-4. There exists a Banach space which is not weakly sequentially complete.

Proof. Let C0 denotes all sequences converging to 0. We claim that (C0)∗=ℓ1. It follows directly that ℓ1⊂C0∗. Since C0⊂span{ek}k≥1―, T∈C0∗ is in form of

T:x=∑k≥1ckek↦∑k≥1T(ek)ck.

Then we claim that {T(ek)}k≥1∈ℓ1. If not, then ∑k≥1|T(ek)|=∞. The following lemma proves the existence of x∈C0 such that T(c)=∞.

Lemma. There is no slowest rate of divergence of a sequence.

Proof of the lemma. Let {Dk}k≥1 be a positive series such that ∑k≥1Dk=∞. We claim the existence of {dk}k≥1 such that ∑k≥1dk=∞ while limk→∞dkDk=0.

Indeed, dk=DkD1+⋯Dk−1 is what we desired. This is due to

  • limk→∞dkDk=limk→∞1D1+⋯Dk−1=0,
  • ∑k≥1dk>∑k≥1∫D1+⋯Dk−1D1+⋯+Dkdxx=∞.

◻

It yields that C0∗=ℓ1.

Take ℓ1∋T=(a1,a2,…), xn=∑k=1nek. Then

|T(xm)−T(xn)|≤∑i=m+1n|ai|,n>m.

Since T∈ℓ1, {T(xn)}n≥1 is Cauchy sequence. However, xn⇀(1,1,…)∉C0, thus C0 is not weakly sequentially complete.

◻

Even though normed topology and weak topology distincts in each infinite dimensional normed linear space, the following propositon always holds.

Proposition 5-5. The space of linear continuous functionals always coincides in normed topology and weak topology.

Proof. By definition of weak topology, it is clear that each f∈X∗ is continuous in (X,σ(X,X∗)). Conversely, Let f≠0 be continuous in (X,σ(X,X∗)). There exists a weak neighbourhood of 0, defined by

V={x∈X∣|fi(x)|<ε,i=1,2,…,n}⊂{x∣|f(x)|<1}.

For each x0∈∩i=1nker⁡fi, λx0∈V for each λ∈R. As a consequence, f(λx0)≡0. It reveals that f is a linear conbination of fi's.

◻
